messages.content: <image>Review this X-ray and provide detailed FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: PICC line on the right is projecting with its tip in the mediastinum and appears to cross the midline, raising concern for potential arterial location. The PICC line is now visualized in the mid SVC. Small right pleural effusion. Moderate cardiomegaly.
<image>Interpret this X-ray image and summarize the FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: Indwelling support and monitoring devices are in standard position. Cardiac silhouette is enlarged. Pulmonary edema shows improvement with residual asymmetrical edema worse on the right than the left. Small pleural effusions are present.
<image>Examine this X-ray image and describe the FINDINGS.
FINDINGS: There is a left IJ catheter that extends to the upper portion of the SVC. No evidence of pneumothorax.
<image>As an imaging expert, review this X-ray and share the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: Moderately enlarged heart size. Both lung volumes are improved. Minimal bilateral pleural effusions. Bilateral lower lung atelectasis are present but improved. Mediastinal and hilar contours are normal. Status post median sternotomy with intact sternal sutures. Mild-to-moderate atherosclerotic calcification in the aortic arch. Internal jugular line through left-sided approach terminates at lower SVC. No discrete lung opacities concerning for pneumonia. IMPRESSION: Moderately enlarged heart, minimal bilateral pleural effusions and improved lung aeration.
<image>Review this X-ray and provide a detailed FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: Midline sternotomy wires are noted. The left IJ central venous catheter has been removed. There is improved aeration in the lung bases. The heart is markedly enlarged. There is no sign of pneumonia or overt CHF. Bony structures are intact. Aortic calcifications noted. IMPRESSION: Stable cardiomegaly without signs of pneumonia or CHF.
<image>Review this chest X-ray and provide the FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: The mediastinal drain tube has been removed. There is no pneumothorax. Both lung volumes are very low. Bilateral, right side more than left side, moderate pulmonary edema has improved. Widened cardiomediastinal silhouette is present; this appearance could be exacerbation from low lung volumes. Patient is status post median sternotomy with intact sternal sutures.
<image>Examine this X-ray image and describe the FINDINGS.
FINDINGS: There is substantial enlargement of the cardiomediastinal silhouette and moderate pulmonary edema with bilateral pleural effusions. Monitoring and support devices are present.
<image>Analyze this chest X-ray and give the FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: Right internal jugular sheath ends at upper SVC. A single mediastinal drain tube is present on the right side. The mediastinum remains widened post-operatively. Bilateral, confluent, lung opacities suggesting moderate pulmonary edema show asymmetric improvement with better resolution on the left side compared to the right. Minimal bilateral pleural effusions are present.
<image>Give a radiology report based on the chest x-ray image, including FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: The chest demonstrates low lung volumes. There is no pleural effusion or pneumothorax. Heart size is top normal. Hilar and mediastinal silhouettes are unremarkable. There is perihilar vascular congestion. Interstitial markings are prominent, suggest possible mild interstitial pulmonary edema. Right-sided Port-A-Cath is in stable position projecting over cavoatrial junction.
<image>As a radiologist, analyze this X-ray and summarize the FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: Complete resolution of the pleural effusions. Moderate cardiomegaly without evidence of pulmonary edema. Small basal parenchymal scars but no evidence of recent pneumonia. Moderate tortuosity of the thoracic aorta. Calcified bronchial walls.
<image>As an imaging expert, review this X-ray and share the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: Mild pulmonary edema. Increased opacity at left lung base suggesting atelectasis and/or combination of atelectasis and edema. Small left pleural effusion is presumed. Heart size is normal. Cardiomediastinal silhouette is unremarkable. Mild-to-moderate atherosclerotic calcification is present in the aortic arch. IMPRESSION: Mild pulmonary edema and presumed small left pleural effusion.
<image>Examine this X-ray image and describe the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: Bilateral perihilar interstitial abnormality consistent with known interstitial lung disease. Bilateral ground-glass opacity and interstitial thickening, predominantly radiating from the hila. Moderate cardiomegaly. Aortic arch calcifications present. A right-sided PICC line terminates in the low SVC. A left chest Port-A-Cath terminates in the right atrium. Vertebroplasty changes noted. IMPRESSION: New pulmonary parenchymal abnormalities superimposed on chronic pulmonary fibrosis most likely represents pulmonary edema. Infection is less likely.
<image>As an imaging expert, review this X-ray and share the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: Cardiomegaly is mild. Prominent interstitial lung markings are compatible with known lung fibrosis. Indistinct pulmonary vascular markings are compatible with mild pulmonary edema. No focal consolidation, pleural effusion, or pneumothorax. The catheter of the left chest wall port terminates in the right atrium. Multiple vertebroplasties are present. No displaced rib fracture is identified. IMPRESSION: Mild pulmonary edema superimposed on known lung fibrosis. Severe chronic cardiomegaly and pulmonary hypertension. No displaced rib fracture. Multiple vertebroplasties.
<image>As an imaging expert, review this X-ray and share the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: Pulmonary vascular congestion is present with substantial enlargement of the cardiac silhouette. The possibility of interstitial lung disease cannot be reliably assessed. No acute focal pneumonia. Central catheter remains in place. IMPRESSION: Persistent pulmonary vascular congestion with cardiomegaly.
<image>Review this X-ray and provide a detailed FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: Mild-to-moderate pulmonary edema with interstitial markings. No focal consolidation or pneumothorax. Heart size is moderately enlarged. A left chest wall Port-A-Cath terminates in the RA. The patient is status post multiple vertebroplasties. IMPRESSION: Mild-to-moderate pulmonary edema.
<image>Interpret this X-ray image and summarize the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: Left-sided Port-A-Catheter is in position, terminating at the cavoatrial/right atrial junction. There is diffuse increase in interstitial markings bilaterally consistent with chronic interstitial lung disease with likely overlying pulmonary edema. No definite focal consolidation or pleural effusion. Multilevel vertebroplasties are seen along the thoracic spine. IMPRESSION: Pulmonary edema superimposed on known lung fibrosis.
<image>Please interpret this X-ray and provide the FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: There is evidence of moderate-to-severe pulmonary edema with prominent interstitial component. A small pleural effusion cannot be excluded. Mild cardiomegaly is present. The left pectoral Port-A-Cath remains in stable position.
<image>Interpret this X-ray image and summarize the FINDINGS.
FINDINGS: The bilateral massive parenchymal opacities are present. There is moderate cardiomegaly.
<image>Please interpret this X-ray and provide the FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: Substantial cardiomegaly with bilateral opacifications most likely reflecting pulmonary edema. The possibility of supervening pneumonia would have to be raised in the appropriate clinical setting. Central catheter remains in place. Slight impression on the lower cervical trachea on the right could possibly represent a small thyroid mass.
<image>Analyze this chest X-ray and give the FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: There is substantial cardiomegaly with bilateral opacifications that most likely represent pulmonary edema. More focal opacification at the right base medially could represent a developing consolidation.
<image>Interpret this X-ray image and summarize the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: A Port-A-Cath terminates in the upper right atrium. The cardiac, mediastinal and hilar contours appear normal. Fine reticulation associated with pulmonary fibrosis is present within each lung in extent and distribution. The lung volumes are low. There is no pleural effusion or pneumothorax. Multiple compression deformities including lower thoracic vertebroplasties are noted. IMPRESSION: No evidence of acute disease. Severe pulmonary fibrosis.
<image>Provide the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION for this chest X-ray.

FINDINGS: Left-sided Port-A-Cath is seen entering the left subclavian and terminating within the right atrium and can be withdrawn 3 cm and still remains within the low SVC. There is mild-to-moderate pulmonary edema and small bilateral pleural effusions. Low lung volumes are noted. Heart is enlarged. There is no pneumothorax. IMPRESSION: Left-sided Port-A-Cath placement, terminates within the right atrium. Can be withdrawn 3 cm and still remain within the low SVC.
<image>Review this X-ray and provide a detailed FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: Right basilar nodular opacification is present. There is a moderate layering pulmonary effusion on the right. There is increased opacification in the right lower lobe. There are no focal opacities concerning for pneumonia. There is no pneumothorax. The cardiomediastinal and hilar contours are stable, with mild cardiomegaly. Pulmonary vascularity is not increased. IMPRESSION: Moderate layering right subpulmonic pleural effusion. Mild right basilar atelectasis.
<image>Review this chest X-ray and provide the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: Right basilar nodular opacification is present. There is a moderate layering pulmonary effusion on the right. There is increased opacification in the right lower lobe. There are no focal opacities concerning for pneumonia. There is no pneumothorax. The cardiomediastinal and hilar contours are stable, with mild cardiomegaly. Pulmonary vascularity is not increased. IMPRESSION: Moderate layering right subpulmonic pleural effusion with right basilar atelectasis.
<image>As an imaging expert, review this X-ray and share the FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: There is a small right pleural effusion with some fluid seen tracking in the minor fissure and which may be partially loculated. Scattered patchy opacities projecting predominantly over the right lung raises concern for an infection, less likely asymmetric edema. There is left basilar atelectasis. The lungs are relatively hyperinflated with flattening of the diaphragms, suggesting chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. The cardiac and mediastinal silhouettes are relatively stable.
<image>Please interpret this X-ray and provide the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: There is no evidence of pneumothorax. There is a moderate subpulmonic pleural effusion. There is a new small left layering pleural effusion. There are no new focal opacities concerning for pneumonia. Cardiomediastinal and hilar contours demonstrate mild tortuosity of the thoracic aorta. Heart size is within normal limits. Pulmonary vascularity is normal. IMPRESSION: No evidence of pneumothorax. Subpulmonic right pleural effusion with little change.
<image>As an imaging expert, review this X-ray and share the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: There are relatively low lung volumes. There is increased opacity over the right hemithorax likely due to right pleural effusion with overlying atelectasis, underlying infectious process not excluded. Possible trace left pleural effusion. The cardiac silhouette is top-normal to mildly enlarged. Mediastinal contours are unremarkable. No pneumothorax is seen. IMPRESSION: Increased opacity over the right hemithorax likely due to right pleural effusion with overlying atelectasis, underlying infectious process not excluded.
<image>Review this chest X-ray and provide the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: Cardiomediastinal contours are stable. The lungs are hyperinflated. There is no pneumothorax. Loculated right pleural effusion is present. Small left effusion is noted. There are no evident thickening lung abnormality. Degenerative changes in the thoracic spine are present. IMPRESSION: Loculated right pleural effusion.
<image>Examine this X-ray image and describe the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: Cardiomediastinal and hilar contours are stable. The heart is top-normal in size. There is diffusely increased opacity throughout the right lung, which is in part related to a chronic loculated effusion with focal opacities suspicious for areas of infection. The left lung is clear. There is no pneumothorax. Pleural thickening is noted at the base of the left lung. Bilateral pleural calcifications are present at the lung bases. IMPRESSION: Diffusely increased opacity throughout the right lung is related to a chronic loculated right effusion and multifocal opacities worrisome for pneumonia.
<image>Give a radiology report based on the chest x-ray image, including FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: Cardiomediastinal and hilar contours are stable. The heart is top-normal in size. There is diffusely increased opacity throughout the right lung, which is in part related to a chronic loculated effusion with new focal opacities suspicious for areas of infection. The left lung is clear. There is no pneumothorax. Pleural thickening is noted at the base of the left lung. Bilateral pleural calcifications are present at the lung bases. IMPRESSION: Diffusely increased opacity throughout the right lung is related to a chronic loculated right effusion and multifocal opacities worrisome for pneumonia.
<image>As a radiologist, analyze this X-ray and summarize the FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: Indwelling support and monitoring devices are in position. Cardiomediastinal contours are stable. Left retrocardiac atelectasis has improved. There is an area of confluent increased opacity in the right infrahilar region which may reflect atelectasis, aspiration, or developing infection.
<image>Provide the FINDINGS for this chest X-ray.
FINDINGS: The heart is moderately enlarged. There is a right IJ Cordis with tip in the upper SVC. There is mild pulmonary vascular re-distribution, but no definite infiltrates or effusion.
<image>Interpret this X-ray image and summarize the FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: Nasogastric tube placement with distal tip and sideport below the gastroesophageal junction. Endotracheal tube and right IJ central line are in appropriate position. Cardiomegaly is present. Left retrocardiac opacity is noted. Prominence of the pulmonary vascular markings is seen, consistent with mild pulmonary edema. Atelectasis is present at the left lung base.
<image>Examine this X-ray image and describe the FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: The PICC extends to the left brachiocephalic vein before its junction with the superior vena cava. Low lung volumes may account for some prominence of the transverse diameter of the heart. Bibasilar opacification most likely reflects atelectatic changes. Possibility of supervening pneumonia would have to be considered in the appropriate clinical setting. The pulmonary vascular congestion is present.
<image>Review this chest X-ray and provide the FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: The tip of the endotracheal tube measures approximately 6.5 cm above the carina. Nasogastric tube courses beyond the lower margin of the image in the distal stomach. The left hemidiaphragm is not sharply seen with increased opacification in the retrocardiac region, consistent with volume loss in the left lower lobe and areas of plate-like atelectasis. Mild pulmonary vascular congestion is present.
<image>Provide the FINDINGS for this chest X-ray.

FINDINGS: Cardiomegaly with retrocardiac atelectasis and possible small left pleural effusion. Mild pulmonary edema. Areas of atelectasis at the right lung base. No new parenchymal opacities. No pneumothorax.
<image>Provide the FINDINGS for this chest X-ray.

FINDINGS: Cardiomegaly with retrocardiac atelectasis and possible small left pleural effusion. Mild pulmonary edema. Areas of atelectasis at the right lung base. No parenchymal opacities. No pneumothorax.
<image>Give a radiology report based on the chest x-ray image, including FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: There is minimal enlargement of the cardiomediastinal contours consistent with mild chronic heart failure. Obscuration of the pulmonary vascular markings in the right lung base is consistent with trace pulmonary edema. Bibasilar atelectasis is present. The lungs are otherwise clear. There is no pneumothorax or pleural effusion. A left internal jugular central venous catheter, an endotracheal tube, and an orogastric tube are appropriately positioned. Atherosclerotic calcification of the aortic arch and bilateral glenohumeral joint degenerative changes are noted. IMPRESSION: 1. Mild chronic congestive heart failure with trace pulmonary edema at the right lung base. 2. Bibasilar atelectasis.
<image>Review this chest X-ray and provide the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: Tracheostomy tube is present. There is no pneumothorax or pleural effusion. There is a hazy veil-like opacity in the right upper lung zone which may be consolidation, atelectasis or artifact. Heart size appears enlarged. Bony structures are intact. IMPRESSION: Hazy opacity in the right upper and mid lungs which may be infectious in etiology, atelectasis or artifact.
<image>Review this chest X-ray and provide the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: An endotracheal tube, NG tube, and right upper extremity PICC with its tip at the cavoatrial junction are present. There is left lower lobe opacity. No large pleural effusion or pneumothorax. The cardiac silhouette is moderately enlarged, mediastinal contours show calcification of the aortic arch. IMPRESSION: Mild retrocardiac opacification, pneumonia vs. atelectasis.
<image>Examine this X-ray image and describe the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: The lungs are clear of large confluent consolidation. Cardiac silhouette enlarged. Calcifications noted at the aortic arch. Degenerative changes noted at the glenohumeral joints bilaterally. Osseous and soft tissue structures otherwise unremarkable. IMPRESSION: No definite acute cardiopulmonary process. Enlarged cardiac silhouette.
<image>Examine this X-ray image and describe the FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: The right basal opacity in the infrahilar area persists. There is decreased visibility of the left hemidiaphragm, suggesting either atelectasis or small left pleural effusion. Moderate cardiomegaly is present. The right costophrenic sinus is unremarkable.
<image>Analyze this chest X-ray and give the FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: The right basal opacity in the infrahilar area persists. There is decreased visibility of the left hemidiaphragm, suggesting either atelectasis or small left pleural effusion. Moderate cardiomegaly is present. The right costophrenic sinus is unremarkable.
<image>As an imaging expert, review this X-ray and share the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: Tracheostomy noted. Cardiomediastinal silhouette is stable; bulging of the pulmonary outflow tract reflects enlargement of pulmonary arteries and suggests underlying pulmonary arterial hypertension. Pulmonary edema shows improvement. Small right pleural effusion is stable. Bibasilar opacifications are noted and are suggestive of atelectasis or consolidation. IMPRESSION: 1. Bibasilar opacities are consistent with atelectasis or consolidation and pneumonia should be considered in the appropriate clinical context. 2. Improved pulmonary edema.
<image>Analyze this chest X-ray and give the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: A hazy opacity is present in the right lung which may represent aspiration, pleural effusion or hemorrhage. Retrocardiac opacity at the left base is present. Moderate cardiomegaly is noted. Slight prominence of the pulmonary vasculature with cephalization and enlarged pulmonary arteries are consistent with mild pulmonary edema. Tracheostomy tube is in place. There are no displaced rib fractures. IMPRESSION: 1. Hazy opacity in the right lung which may represent aspiration versus pleural effusion or hemorrhage. 2. Mild pulmonary edema. 3. No displaced rib fractures.
<image>Review this chest X-ray and provide the FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: There is an endotracheal tube whose distal tip is 6.2 cm above the carina appropriately sited. There is a left-sided IJ line with distal lead tip in the mid SVC. There is a nasogastric tube whose tip and sideport are below the GE junction. There is a persistent left retrocardiac opacity. There is some atelectasis at the left lung base. There is aeration at the right lung base. No pneumothoraces are seen.
<image>Give a radiology report based on the chest x-ray image, including FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: There is an endotracheal tube whose distal tip is 6.2 cm above the carina appropriately sited. There is a left-sided IJ line with distal lead tip in the mid SVC. There is a nasogastric tube whose tip and sideport are below the GE junction. There is a persistent left retrocardiac opacity. There is some atelectasis at the left lung base. There is improved aeration at the right lung base. No pneumothoraces are seen.
<image>As a radiologist, analyze this X-ray and summarize the FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: The ET tube is 3.5 cm above the carina. The NG tube tip is at least in the stomach. Right IJ Cordis tip is in the proximal SVC. The heart size is moderately enlarged. There is ill-defined vasculature and alveolar infiltrate, right greater than left, likely representing fluid overload.
<image>Please interpret this X-ray and provide the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: Tracheostomy tube is noted. Left PICC tip is not clearly delineated. There is mild pulmonary vascular congestion. Streaky opacities at the lung bases suggestive of atelectasis; however infection cannot be excluded. Cardiomediastinal silhouette is stable as are the osseous and soft tissue structures. IMPRESSION: Pulmonary vascular congestion. Bibasilar opacities potentially due to atelectasis; however, infection is not excluded.
<image>Give a radiology report based on the chest x-ray image, including FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: There is improvement in the extent and severity of the parenchymal opacities. The cardiac silhouette remains unchanged in size. No pleural effusions. The nasogastric tube is absent. Endotracheal tube and the right internal jugular vein introduction sheath are in stable position.
<image>Review this chest X-ray and provide the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: Left PICC tip is seen terminating in the region of the distal left brachiocephalic vein. Tracheostomy tube is in standard position. The heart is moderately enlarged. Marked calcification of the aortic knob is present. Mild pulmonary vascular congestion is noted. Bibasilar streaky airspace opacities are present. No pleural effusion is identified. No pneumothorax is seen. Percutaneous gastrostomy tube is present in the left upper quadrant. IMPRESSION: 1. Left PICC tip terminates in the distal left brachiocephalic vein. 2. Mild pulmonary vascular congestion. 3. Bibasilar streaky opacities likely reflective of atelectasis. No pleural effusion.
<image>Analyze this chest X-ray and give the FINDINGS.
FINDINGS: No evidence of pneumothorax. Low lung volumes with substantial mass in the right paratracheal region.
<image>As a radiologist, analyze this X-ray and summarize the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: Rounded calcified nodule in the region of the posterior right lung base is seen and represents calcified granuloma, likely secondary to prior granulomatous disease. Pretracheal lymph node conglomerate and right hilar lymph nodes are present. No focal consolidation is seen. There is no pleural effusion or pneumothorax. Cardiac and mediastinal silhouettes are stable with possible slight decrease in right paratracheal prominence. IMPRESSION: No radiographic findings to suggest pneumonia.
<image>Analyze this chest X-ray and give the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: A round calcified pulmonary nodule is present in the posterior right lung base, consistent with granulomatous disease. There is increased opacity at the right hilum likely representing an enlarged right hilar lymph node. Fullness at the right paratracheal region corresponds to a right mediastinal lymph node conglomerate. No pleural effusion, pneumothorax or focal consolidation is present. The patient has sternotomy wires in place. The cardiac silhouette is normal in size. IMPRESSION: No acute cardiopulmonary process.
<image>Provide the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION for this chest X-ray.

FINDINGS: A round calcified pulmonary nodule is present in the posterior right lung base, consistent with granulomatous disease. There is increased opacity at the right hilum likely representing an enlarged right hilar lymph node. Fullness at the right paratracheal region corresponds to a right mediastinal lymph node conglomerate. No pleural effusion, pneumothorax or focal consolidation is present. The patient has sternotomy wires in place. The cardiac silhouette is normal in size. IMPRESSION: No acute cardiopulmonary process.
<image>Interpret this X-ray image and summarize the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: The lungs are low in volume. There is no focal airspace consolidation to suggest pneumonia. A 1.2-cm calcified granuloma is noted below the medial aspect of the right hemidiaphragm. No pleural effusions or pulmonary edema. There is no pneumothorax. The inferior sternotomy wire is fractured. Surgical clips and vascular markers in the thorax are present. IMPRESSION: No evidence of acute cardiopulmonary process.
<image>Review this X-ray and provide a detailed FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: There is peribronchial thickening and impaction with extensive bibasilar bronchiectasis. Hyperexpansion of the lungs is consistent with emphysema and the cardiac size is normal. No evidence of pulmonary edema or acute focal pneumonia. IMPRESSION: Severe bronchiectasis and emphysema.
<image>Interpret this X-ray image and summarize the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: There is peribronchial thickening and impaction with extensive bibasilar bronchiectasis. Hyperexpansion of the lungs is consistent with emphysema and the cardiac size is normal. No evidence of pulmonary edema. No evidence of acute focal pneumonia. IMPRESSION: Severe bronchiectasis and emphysema.
<image>Review this chest X-ray and provide the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: The lungs are hyperinflated, suggesting chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. No focal consolidation, pleural effusion, or evidence of pneumothorax is seen. The cardiac and mediastinal silhouettes are unremarkable. Hilar contours are normal. Peribronchovascular ground-glass opacities at the left greater than right lung bases may be present. Several pulmonary nodules measuring up to 3 mm are not well appreciated. IMPRESSION: No acute cardiopulmonary process.
<image>Interpret this X-ray image and summarize the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: The lungs remain hyperinflated, suggesting chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. No focal consolidation, pleural effusion, or evidence of pneumothorax is seen. The cardiac and mediastinal silhouettes are unremarkable. Hilar contours are normal. There are peribronchovascular ground-glass opacities at the left greater than right lung bases. Several pulmonary nodules measuring up to 3 mm are present. IMPRESSION: No acute cardiopulmonary process. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease with pulmonary nodules and ground-glass opacities.
<image>Provide the FINDINGS for this chest X-ray.

FINDINGS: As compared to the previous radiograph, there is no relevant change. Moderate-to-severe overinflation with known areas of bronchiectasis and perifocal parenchymal opacities. The opacities are unchanged in distribution and severity. Normal size of the cardiac silhouette. Normal hilar and mediastinal structures. No newly appeared focal parenchymal changes.
<image>Provide the FINDINGS for this chest X-ray.

FINDINGS: As compared to the previous radiograph, there is no relevant change. Moderate-to-severe overinflation with known areas of bronchiectasis and perifocal parenchymal opacities. The opacities are unchanged in distribution and severity. Normal size of the cardiac silhouette. Normal hilar and mediastinal structures. No newly appeared focal parenchymal changes.
<image>Give a radiology report based on the chest x-ray image, including FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: There is a subtle opacity at the right lung base, in the medial aspect of the lung. The opacities are located in an area of bronchiectasis. Given the clinical presentation, pneumonia must be suspected. The radiograph shows extensive overinflation with bronchiectasis but no pleural effusions or other parenchymal changes. Normal size of the cardiac silhouette. Unchanged position of the nasogastric tube.
<image>As an imaging expert, review this X-ray and share the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: No focal consolidation, pleural effusion, or pneumothorax is seen. Heart and mediastinal contours are within normal limits. Lungs are again noted to be hyperinflated. IMPRESSION: Stable chest radiographs without acute change.
<image>Review this X-ray and provide a detailed FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: Bilateral lower lung bronchiectasis with peribronchial opacities. The right lower and medial lung shows improvement in peribronchial opacities. There are no new opacities. Lungs are mildly hyperinflated. Heart size, mediastinal and hilar contours are normal. No pleural effusion. IMPRESSION: Bilateral lower lobe bronchiectasis with improved right lower medial lung peribronchial consolidation.
<image>As a radiologist, analyze this X-ray and summarize the FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: The ET tube is low, 1.5 cm above the carina. There are increased lung markings bilaterally with bilateral basilar atelectasis/infiltrate/aspiration. An IJ line tip is at the cavoatrial junction.
<image>As an imaging expert, review this X-ray and share the FINDINGS.
FINDINGS: The ET tube is positioned 1.4 cm above the carina. The lungs appear stable. The right IJ line tip remains at the cavoatrial junction.
<image>Examine this X-ray image and describe the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: There is mild cardiomegaly. The aorta is tortuous and calcified. The mediastinal and hilar contours appear normal. There is mild interstitial abnormality with prominence of central pulmonary vascularity, suggesting mild vascular congestion. Patchy streaky opacities in the right mid and lower lung suggest minor scarring or atelectasis. No definite pleural effusion or pneumothorax is demonstrated. IMPRESSION: Findings suggest mild pulmonary vascular congestion.
<image>Give a radiology report based on the chest x-ray image, including FINDINGS.
FINDINGS: Cardiac silhouette is enlarged with pulmonary vascular congestion and interstitial edema. Patchy bibasilar atelectasis is present.
<image>Interpret this X-ray image and summarize the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: There is a somewhat heterogeneous but generally diffuse mild interstitial abnormality suggesting slight pulmonary congestion. There is a slightly more confluent right upper lobe opacity of uncertain significance, quite vague, and there is also focal left infrahilar opacity. There is no definite pleural effusion or pneumothorax. IMPRESSION: Findings suggesting mild vascular congestion. Focal patchy right upper lobe and left infrahilar opacities of uncertain significance but possibly due to atelectasis or scarring. If infection is clinically suspected, followup radiographs could be considered.
<image>Interpret this X-ray image and summarize the FINDINGS and IMPRESSION.

FINDINGS: There is a somewhat heterogeneous but generally diffuse mild interstitial abnormality suggesting slight pulmonary congestion. There is a slightly more confluent right upper lobe opacity of uncertain significance, quite vague, and there is also focal left infrahilar opacity. There is no definite pleural effusion or pneumothorax. IMPRESSION: Findings suggesting mild vascular congestion. Focal patchy right upper lobe and left infrahilar opacities of uncertain significance but possibly due to atelectasis or scarring. If infection is clinically suspected, followup radiographs could be considered.
<image>As a radiologist, analyze this X-ray and summarize the FINDINGS.
FINDINGS: There are extensive bilateral parenchymal opacities, bilateral pleural effusions, cardiomegaly, and basal atelectasis. No new opacities. Monitoring and support devices are present.
<image>As an imaging expert, review this X-ray and share the FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: Small bilateral pleural effusions with evidence of relatively extensive bilateral probably atelectatic consolidations. Mild-to-moderate fluid overload. No focal parenchymal opacities. Extensive calcifications and tortuosity of the thoracic aorta.
<image>Provide the FINDINGS for this chest X-ray.

FINDINGS: Bilateral parenchymal opacities are present, more prominent on the right than the left. Cardiomegaly and small bilateral pleural effusions are noted. There are areas of basal atelectasis. The endotracheal tube and right-sided central venous access line are in appropriate position.
<image>As an imaging expert, review this X-ray and share the FINDINGS.

FINDINGS: There is a new dense right central opacity approximately 7 cm x 3 cm. Given the rapid onset of this finding, the differential is limited to airspace consolidation or atelectasis. Given previous radiographic evidence of slow neo-esophageal/gastric emptying, it is possible that patient had aspirated contrast material. This would also explain the dense opacity. However, other radiopaque fluid could be filling the airspace in this region. Adjacent to this dense opacity are ill-defined peripheral opacities which is not matched on the contralateral side. The left lung is unremarkable. There is no pleural effusion or pneumothorax. There is pronounced flattening of the hemidiaphragms. The cardiomediastinal silhouette is unchanged and within normal limits. The pleural surfaces are unremarkable. IMPRESSION: Large dense right central opacity which may represent collapse or airspace consolidation with adjacent area of asymmetric pulmonary edema. Given history of lymphadenopathy, collapse could be secondary to nodal compression of an airway. Alternatively, given recent history of oral contrast and poor gastric emptying, opacity may represent aspirated contrast material. Consolidation also could be secondary to a fistula between the neo-esophagus and the right lung. If this finding represent consolidation, the radiopaque material cannot be identified definitely and may represent fluid or pus. CT imaging is highly recommended for further evaluation of this finding.
